vocabulary.definition: First person singular pronoun; refers to the speaker.

examples.english: I am the one who will cook the food.

vocabulary.notes: Subject form is 'aku', object form can be 'kanaku'.

vocabulary.definition: Second person singular pronoun; refers to the person being addressed.
First person plural inclusive pronoun; includes both speaker and listener.

examples.tausug: Kita madtu ha bay ni Inda.
examples.english: We (you and I) will go to Inda's house.

vocabulary.notes: Different from verb 'kita' (to see). Inclusive 'we' includes listener.

vocabulary.definition: First person plural exclusive pronoun; includes speaker but excludes listener.

examples.tausug: Kami madtu ha iskul, ikaw ha bay.
examples.english: We (my group) will go to school, you stay at home.

vocabulary.notes: Exclusive 'we' does not include the person being spoken to.

vocabulary.definition: Third person singular pronoun; refers to someone other than speaker or listener.

examples.english: He/She was the one who read the letter.

vocabulary.notes: Gender-neutral in Tausug; context determines if male or female.

vocabulary.definition: Third person plural pronoun; refers to a group of people not including speaker or listener.

examples.tausug: Sila in manga nagdula ha guwa.
examples.english: They are the ones playing outside.

vocabulary.definition: Demonstrative pronoun referring to something near the speaker.
Demonstrative pronoun referring to something away from the speaker.
Tausug pronouns change based on person, number, and inclusivity.
vocabulary.notes: Kita = you + me, Kami = me + others (not you). This distinction is important in Tausug culture.
